claims.claim: TRAPPIST-1 b has an atmosphere and is not a bare rock

evidence.quote: The dataset provides meaningful evidence against a strictly airless interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b
A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior

claims.caveat: This is a single-planet study and atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain enough that follow-up spectroscopy is essential.

claims.claim: There is non-zero heat redistribution from day to night side indicating atmospheric transport

evidence.quote: Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) | 0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit | Non-zero redistribution is favored
A non-zero redistribution parameter implies transport beyond an immediate bare-rock reradiation limit

claims.caveat: Retrieval assumptions including circulation models affect quantitative posteriors, and night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints.

claims.claim: CO2 absorption at 15 microns is detected in the atmosphere

evidence.quote: 15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate 96 ppm | Flat-spectrum null | Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption
Spectral structure near 15 um provides composition-sensitive evidence, especially for CO2-rich scenarios

claims.caveat: Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features, and O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out.

claims.claim: Atmosphere-bearing models provide a better fit to the combined data than no-atmosphere models

evidence.quote: Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere) 7.4 | 1.0 baseline ratio | Atmosphere-bearing models better explain combined data products
Joint constraints from phase curve and spectrum are stronger than either observable alone

claims.caveat: Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
